greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(0) = 1, a(1) = 2; for n > 1, if n is even, then a(n) = 2*a(n/2), and if n is odd, a(n) = A283980(a((n-1)/2)).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..8192
formula: a(0) = 1, a(1) = 2; for n > 1, if n is odd, a(n) = A283980(a((n-1)/2)), and if n is even, then a(n) = 2*a(n/2).
a(2^n) = 2^(1+n). [And all the terms following after a(2^n) are > 2^(1+n).]
example: This irregular table can be represented as a binary tree. Each child to the left is obtained by doubling the parent, and each child to the right is obtained by applying A283980 to the parent:
A329886 is the mirror image of the same tree.
mathematica: {1}~Join~Nest[Append[#1, If[EvenQ@ #2, 2 #1[[#2/2]], (Times @@ Map[#1^#2 & @@ # &, FactorInteger[#] /. {p_, e_} /; e > 0 :> {Prime[PrimePi@ p + 1], e}] - Boole[# == 1])*2^IntegerExponent[#, 2] &[#1[[(#2 - 1)/2]] ]]] & @@ {#, Length@ # + 1} &, {2}, 55] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Dec 29 2019 *)
program: A283980(n) = {my(f=factor(n)); prod(i=1, #f~, my(p=f[i, 1], e=f[i, 2]); if(p==2, 6, nextprime(p+1))^e)}; \\ From A283980
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 24 2019
